questions.text: Which of the following groups is not included in the high-risk core population for HIV transmission?

options.label: C
options.text: Men who have sex with men

questions.explanation:
Group

Category

Rationale

IV drug users (IDUs)

Core

High HIV risk due to needle sharing and risky sexual behavior.

Female sex workers (FSWs)

Core

Engage in frequent unprotected sex, increasing exposure.

Men who have sex with men (MSM)

Core

Higher prevalence of unprotected anal sex, a major HIV transmission route.

Long-distance truck drivers (LDTD)

Bridge

They interact with core populations (FSWs, IDUs) and spread HIV to the general population but are not core transmitters themselves.

questions.text: Malaria detection on the field is done by which of the following?
questions.correct_answer: C. HRP2 antigen / Rapid diagnostic test
questions.explanation:
Method

Principle

Best Used In

Limitations

Thick smear

Concentrates parasites for better detection

Diagnosis in labs with microscopy

Requires staining and expertise

Thin smear

Used to identify species and parasite morphology

Differentiating Plasmodium species

Less sensitive in low parasitemia

HRP2 antigen / RDT

Detects malarial antigens (HRP2 or pLDH)

Field settings, rapid diagnosis

Cannot detect low parasitemia or HRP2-deleted strains

Quantitative Buffy Coat (QBC)

Fluorescent staining of parasites in WBC fraction

High-sensitivity lab settings

Expensive, requires specialized equipment

questions.text: A fruit farmer presents with fever, respiratory difficulties, and neurological complications. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Nipah

questions.text: A man occasionally eats outside due to traveling reasons. He presents to a physician with abdominal pain for 4 days, along with a history of fever and bradycardia. Which test is used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Blood cultu

questions.text: If the incubation period of a disease is 5-14 days, what should be the recommended quarantine period?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - 14

questions.text: The period between the entry of an organism into the host and the time when the host becomes maximally infectious is referred to as?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - G

questions.text: A 35-year-old male soldier complained of being plagued by a painful, erosive lesion near his earlobe since his return from his duty in the desert area. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and general physical examinations reveal no other abnormalities. The punch biopsy of the leading edge of the erosion reveals the given findings. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Kala-azar/ Black sickness/Dum-dum fever/Sandfly disease/ Visceral Leishmaniasis

Organism

Protozoan

Epidemiology

Endemic in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, West Bengal

Types
  1. Visceral (Kala-Azar): L. donovani
  2. Cutaneous: L. tropica
  3. Mucocutaneous: L. braziliensis
  4. Post-kala-azar dermal (PKLD): Immune response

Reservoir
  • Humans (non-zoonotic)

Vector
  • Sandfly (Phlebotomus argentipes): has hairy wings.

Environmental
  • Peak outbreak: November to April

Mechanism of transmission
  • Bite of sandfly
  • Blood transfusion (rare)

Incubation period
  • 10 days to 2 years. (1-4 months average)

Clinical features
  • Visceral: Fever, Weight loss, Hepatosplenomegaly, Anemia.
  • Cutaneous: Painful skin ulcers
  • Mucocutaneous: Rapid mucosal destruction of nose and oropharynx
  • PKDL: Skin nodules filled with micro-organisms

Diagnosis
  • Rapid diagnostic kits: rk39-dipstick test.
    • Used for field surveys.
  • Biopsy (Gold standard): Leishmania Donovan bodies (amastigotes)

Sandfly control measures
  • DDT: 1-2gm/m2.
  • BHC (benzene hexachloride)

Treatment
  • DOC: Single dose Liposomal amphotericin-B (LAMB)10 mg/kg
  • Alternatives:
    • Miltefosine + Paramomycin
    • Pentamidine

questions.text: Mark the incorrect statement regarding Nipah virus:

options.label: A
options.text: It is transmitted through bat urine

questions.explanation:
Nipah virus

Natural reservoir

Bats

Modes of transmission

  • Direct contact with infected animals
  • Body secretion (blood, urine, faeces, seminal fluid) (Option A)
  • Consumption of contaminated food products (palm sap or fruits)

Incubation period

4-14 days

Clinical features
  • Fever, chills, headache
  • Encephalitis (M/C), acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • Multiorgan failure, GIT haemorrhage (case fatality rate- 40-70%)

questions.text: Match the following diseases with their respective incubation period: a. Chicken pox 1. 10-12 days b. Mumps 2. 14-16 days c. Measles 3. 16-18 days d. Syphilis 4. 2-4 weeks (average 21 days)
questions.explanation:
Disease

Causative Agent

Mode of Transmission

Incubation Period

Remarks

Measles

Measles virus

Droplet & droplet nuclei

10–14 days

Rash appears ~14 days; endemic with periodic epidemics

Mumps

Mumps virus

Droplet & direct contact

14–21 days (avg 16–18 days)

Iceberg phenomenon; endemic

Rubella

Rubella virus

Droplet & droplet nuclei

14–21 days (avg ~18 days)

Epidemics occur every 5–7 years

Chickenpox (Varicella)

Varicella-zoster virus

Airborne, droplet, direct contact

10–21 days (avg 14–16 days)

Highly contagious

Pertussis (Whooping Cough)

Bordetella pertussis

Droplet & direct contact

7–14 days (may extend to 3 weeks)

Endemic; catarrhal stage follows incubation

Diphtheria

Corynebacterium diphtheriae

Droplet, contact with infected secretions

2–5 days (range up to 10 days)

Requires antitoxin + antibiotics

Influenza

Influenza virus

Droplet, direct contact

1–4 days (avg ~2 days)

Rapid onset; seasonal epidemics

COVID-19

SARS-CoV-2

Droplet, aerosol, contact

2–14 days (avg 5–6 days)

Incubation varies by variant

Syphilis

Treponema pallidum

Sexual, transplacental

10–90 days (avg ~21 days)

Chancre appears ~3 weeks post-exposure

Hepatitis A

HAV

Feco-oral

15–50 days (avg ~28 days)

Waterborne outbreaks possible

Hepatitis B

HBV

Parenteral, sexual, perinatal

30–180 days (avg ~75 days)

Asymptomatic during incubation

Tetanus

Clostridium tetani

Contaminated wounds

3–21 days (avg ~8 days)

Severity ↑ with shorter incubation

Rabies

Rabies virus

Animal bites (saliva)

1–3 months (can range 1 week–1 year)

Depends on bite site & viral load

Typhoid Fever

Salmonella typhi

Feco-oral

7–14 days

Gradual onset of fever

Cholera

Vibrio cholerae

Feco-oral (contaminated water)

2 hours–5 days (avg 1–2 days)

Sudden explosive outbreaks

Dengue

Dengue virus

Mosquito-borne (Aedes aegypti)

4–7 days

After bite of infected mosquito

Leptospirosis

Leptospira interrogans

Contact with animal urine-contaminated water

2–30 days (avg 7–12 days)

Occupational risk; biphasic illness

Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease

Coxsackie A virus

Feco-oral, respiratory secretions

3–6 days

Common in young children

Polio

Poliovirus

Feco-oral, oral-oral

7–14 days

May be asymptomatic or paralytic

HIV/AIDS (Acute Phase)

HIV

Sexual, blood, perinatal

2–6 weeks

Acute retroviral syndrome during seroconversion

Malaria

Plasmodium spp.

Mosquito-borne (Anopheles)

7–30 days

P. falciparum: shorter incubation

Tuberculosis

Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Airborne

Weeks to months

Latent TB has undefined incubation period

Bacillus cereus food poisoning

Bacillus cereus

Ingestion of contaminated food

1–6 hours

Associated with reheated rice

Staphylococcal food poisoning

Staph. aureus

Ingestion of preformed toxin

1–8 hours

Common in cream/pastry-based food

Botulism

Clostridium botulinum

Ingestion of toxin

18–36 hours

Neuroparalysis; emergency

questions.text: A 32 year old male presented to emergency department with crush injury to the hand. He had a TT injection when he was 25 years old. The wound has been cleaned. What is the recommended next step of management?
A patient has developed hepatitis A for more than 15 days. What is the correct statement ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Acu

questions.text: In which category of bioterrorism, does Anthrax belong?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - CAT A

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in STEP approach?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A  - Blood grou

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came to ER presenting with fever, cough, runny nose, and a characteristic red rash.Which of the following statements about measles disease is incorrect?

options.label: C
options.text: Period of communicability is 14 days after rash

questions.correct_answer: C. Period of communicability is 14 days after rash

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with known HIV infection and presenting with persistent cough, fever, and weight loss, which diagnostic test is considered the investigation of choice for detecting tuberculosis (TB)?
A 40-year-old male with a known case of HIV infection and a CD4 count less than 50 cells/μL. Which of the following infections is he at risk of developing?

A 5-year-old child presenting to a clinic with a history of cough, runny nose, conjunctivitis, fever, and a rash that initially arises behind the ears and then spreads to the chest, back, and abdomen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - M

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presenting with hypopigmented patches, loss of cold sensation followed by hot, touch and pain along with a palpable ulnar nerve. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - L

questions.text: Which vaccines should healthcare workers receive?
questions.explanation:
Vaccine Reason
Hepatitis B Bloodborne transmission risk from patients
Influenza Seasonal spread in hospital settings
MMR Protection against measles, mumps, rubella
Tdap For pertussis, tetanus, diphtheria protection
Varicella For non-immune HCWs, to prevent chickenpox
COVID-19 For pandemic and endemic control
Rabies Only for specific risk groups like lab workers or veterinarians

questions.text: The blood pressure of a population was tracked from childhood to adulthood. It was observed that those who had lower BP in childhood had low BP in adulthood, while those who had higher BP in childhood had high BP in adulthood. This can be best described as:
According to the Colombo plan, which of the following statements regarding cancer treatment is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Help with PET scan units for diagnosis of cancer

questions.correct_answer: D. Setting up cobalt therapy units
questions.explanation:
The Colombo Plan
  • Multilateral agency.
  • Promotes the concept of collective intergovernmental for economic and social development in South and Southeast Asia.
  • Primary focus is on agricultural and industrial development and sometimes on health.
  • Membership - 20 developing countries.
  • 6 non-regional members - Australia, Canada, Japan, New Zealand, UK, USA.
  • Provides Cobalt Radiotherapy Units to Medical Colleges
  • AIIMS in New Delhi was established with financial assistance from New Zealand.

questions.text: A boys' hostel has an outbreak of fever cases with headache, followed by the development of pleomorphic rashes sparing palms and soles. What is the next best step in the management of suspected cases?

options.label: A
options.text: Isolate for 6 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 72 hours of exposure

options.label: B
options.text: Isolate for 12 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 48 hours of exposure

questions.explanation:
Parameter

Details

Chickenpox
  • Seasonal affinity: Winter season
  • Etiology: HHV-3
  • Route of transmission: Respiratory / aerosol route
  • Age group affected: 5-9 years (school going age)
  • Incubation period: 14-16 days
  • Infectivity: 2 days prior to 5 days after the onset of rash
  • SAR:> 90%

Clinical Features
  • Pre-eruptive stage: Sudden onset of mild to moderate fever lasting 2–3 days.
  • Eruptive stage: Centripetal, pleomorphic rash with "Dew drop on rose petal" appearance.

Complications
  • Adults/Immunosuppressed: Pneumonia.
  • Maternal varicella: Low birth weight, microcephaly, cataract, deafness, fetal wastage.
  • Secondary bacterial infection: Cellulitis, osteomyelitis, erysipelas.

Diagnosis
  • PCR: Detecting VZV DNA.
  • Cell culture: From saliva or vesicle fluid.
  • Tzanck smear: Multinucleated giant cells.

Control and Prevention

(Options A, B, and D)
  • Isolation: 6 days after rash appearance.
  • Disinfection: Used specimens with infective secretions.
  • Acyclovir: For adults to prevent complications; not indicated in children.
  • VZV Immunoglobulin: Within 72 hours of exposure, for immunosuppressed individuals.
  • Vaccine: 12–18 months of age; 0.5 ml subcutaneous injection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old homeless man presented with a 1-month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Both sputum smears turned out to be negative, but the chest x-ray ordered was suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management?

options.label: D
options.text: Wait until TB culture results to start ATT

questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Modality

Description

Usage

Sputum Smear Microscopy

Microscopic examination of sputum samples to detect acid-fast bacilli (AFB).

Used for initial screening and diagnosis, especially in resource-limited settings.

Chest X-ray

Imaging done to identify abnormalities suggestive of TB.

Used to support diagnosis when clinical suspicion is high; not definitive for TB diagnosis.

TruNAAT/CBNAAT

Molecular tests that detect Mycobacterial DNA and rifampicin resistance.

Recommended for initial diagnosis due to high sensitivity and specificity; rapid results.

Line Probe Assay (LPA)

Molecular test to detect specific genetic mutations associated with drug resistance (e.g., rifampicin, isoniazid).

Used for detecting drug resistance in confirmed TB cases, not for initial diagnosis.

Tuberculin Skin Test (TST)

A skin test to measure immune response to injected tuberculin protein.

Primarily used for screening latent TB infection; not specific for active TB diagnosis.

Interferon-Gamma Release Assays (IGRAs)

Blood cytokine analysis test that measures immune response to TB antigens.

Used for detecting latent TB infection

Sputum Culture

Growing Mycobacteria from sputum samples to confirm TB and test for drug susceptibility.

Gold standard for TB diagnosis; takes several weeks to obtain results.

Drug Susceptibility Testing (DST)

Testing TB bacteria from patient samples to determine resistance to TB drugs.

Used to guide treatment by identifying drug-resistant strains in confirmed TB cases.

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of category 3 dog bites. He received prophylaxis for a monkey bite 6 months back. What is the next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Wound cleaning + rabies vaccine on day 0 & 3

questions.correct_answer: B. Wound cleaning + rabies vaccine on day 0 & 3

questions.text: Which of the following medications is typically prescribed as the initial treatment for tuberculosis during the first 2 months?
For which of the following airborne infections is it necessary to isolate patients in a separate room?

What are the necessary criteria that need to be fulfilled in order to initiate MDT? 1. Hypopigmented patch with sensory loss 2. Peripheral nerve thickening 3. Peripheral nerve thickening with sensory loss 4. Skin biopsy demonstrating bacilli
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Criteria for Leprosy

1. Hypopigmented or reddish skin lesion with definite sensory loss

2. Thickened peripheral nerve with sensory and/or motor loss

3. Positive slit-skin smear or skin biopsy showing AFB

questions.text: What is the accurate statement concerning preventive measures for typhoid transmission in the community?

options.label: A
options.text: Typhoid vaccine administration is the best method of preventing transmission.

options.label: B
options.text: Hygiene practice and clean sanitation control is more important than the typhoid vaccine.

options.label: C
options.text: In 10% of cases, person-to-person transmission occurs.

options.label: D
options.text: Drug resistance in typhoid is not as big a problem as in TB.

questions.correct_answer: B. Hygiene practice and clean sanitation control is more important than the typhoid vaccine.

questions.text: The drug shown in the image below is administered for:

Which of the following statements regarding drugs used in anti-tubercular treatment are true? A. Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis B. Pyrazinamide is an enzyme inducer C. Rifampicin is used only in the treatment of tuberculosis D. Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase

A child is brought to the PHC with acute diarrhoea. The doctor, based on history, suspects that the child may be suffering from an infection due to Shigella over cholera and proceeds to give ciprofloxacin as the antibiotic. Which of the following points on history, apart from bloody stools, favour the doctor's suspicion?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Presence of fever

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Presence of vomiting (Option C):

questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Infant parasite

questions.text: Based on Globocan 2020 data, which cancer type is the most prevalent among males in India?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Lip and oral cavity

According to the Global Cancer Observatory (GLOBOCAN),

Most common cancer worldwide (Both Genders):

  1. Absolute numbers, Incidence, Both sexes, in 2022 (World Wide)- Lung Cancer.
  2. Age-Standardized Rate (World) per 100 000, Incidence, Both sexes, in 2022- Breast Cancer.

Most common cancer in India in terms of absolute numbers, incidence:

  1. Lip/Oral Cancer in Males
  2. Breast cancer in females

According to the National Cancer Registry, the most common cause of cancer in

  1. Males in India – Lung cancer.
  2. Females in India - Breast cancer.

Ribbon colour

Meaning

Red

HIV/AIDS

Pink

Breast cancer

Light Blue

Prostate cancer

Dark Blue

Colon Cancer

Green
  • Mental illness
  • Liver cancer

Orange/Yellow
  • Suicide prevention
  • Leukaemia
  • Kidney cancer

White

Lung cancer

questions.text: A pregnant woman arrived at the emergency department following an incident where she was scratched by a stray dog while walking on the streets one hour ago. She has only suffered minor abrasions without any bleeding. What course of treatment should be provided to her?

options.label: A
options.text: No treatment as she is pregnant now

options.label: C
options.text: Local wound cleaning and rabies vaccine

options.label: D
options.text: Local wound cleaning, Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins

questions.correct_answer: C. Local wound cleaning and rabies vaccine
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Local wound cleaning and rabies vaccine:

Category

Exposure

Management

Class I

(Option B)

Licks and touch on intact skin (skin integrity not broken)
  • Local wound management: soap, running water, iodine tincture for 15-20 min.

Class II
 

Abrasion, laceration (skin integrity broken)
  • Local wound management
  • Immediate Rabies vaccination

Class III
(Option D)

Bleeding, licks on mucosa/ broken skin, deep tissue injury, all wild animal or bat bite
  • Wound management (avoid suturing)
  • Rabies vaccination
  • Rabies immunoglobulin

questions.text: What treatment should be administered to a patient diagnosed with P. Falciparum malaria from a North-Eastern state?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Artemether plus lumefantrine

Initial parenteral treatment (48 hours)

Follow-up treatment

Quinine

  • Loading dose: 20 mg/kg
  • Maintenance dose : 10 mg/kg TDS

Quinine 10 mg/kg TDS +

  • Doxycycline 3 mg/kg (or)
  • Clindamycin 10 mg/kg (if pregnant / children < 8 years)

Total treatment duration: 7 days
  • Artesunate: 2.4 mg/kg loading dose, then at 12th and 24th hour followed by once a day.
  • Artemether: Loading dose of 3.2 mg/kg; maintenance dose of 1.6 mg/kg per day.
  • Arteether: 150 mg per day for 3 days.

ACT therapy

  • North-eastern states: Age & weight adjusted ACT-AL for 3 days + primaquine on second day.
  • Other states: ACT-SP (Option B) (sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine) for 3 days + primaquine on second day.

questions.text: Re-infection with which of the following will lead to catastrophic symptoms even in the presence of antibodies?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Dengu

questions.text: You are a doctor in a village. A 1-year-old child who is not taking feeds presents with fever and cough for 2 days. On examination, he is calm, with a respiratory rate of 51 breaths/min, and stridor is present. According to IMNCI (integrated management of neonatal and childhood illnesses). How is he classified?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Severe pneu

questions.text: What type of resistance is exhibited by the patient who is unresponsive to Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Ofloxacin, and Kanamycin?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Extensively drug-resistant

Category

Description

Drug sensitive TB

Patients are sensitive to 4 TB drugs: R,H,Z,E (Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol).

Mono-resistant (MR)

Resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.

H-Mono-resistant (H-MR)

Resistant to Isoniazid (H) only.

Rifampicin resistant (RR) (Option C)

Resistant to Rifampicin (R) only.

Multi-drug resistant (MDR) (Option A)

Resistant to both Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H).

Poly-Drug resistant (PDR)

Resistant to 2 drugs other than Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H).

Pre-Xtensive resistant (pre-XDR)

Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone.

Extensive resistant (XDR)

Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone and Group 4 drugs (Bedaquiline, Linezolid, Levo/Moxifloxacin).

questions.text: A diabetic patient comes to you for advice regarding his diet. You advise him to include foods with a low glycemic index in the diet. Which of the following would you advise him for the same?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Papaya

Classification

GI Index Range

Examples

Low GI

55 or less

Most fruits and vegetables (except potatoes, watermelon, sweetcorn), whole grains, pasta foods, beans, lentils, oats, quinoa, guava

Medium GI

56-69

Sucrose, basmati rice, brown rice, dairy products (Options B, C)

High GI

70 and above

Corn flakes, baked potato, some white rice varieties (e.g., jasmine), white bread, candy bar, syrupy foods (Options A)

questions.text: Please match the following colors of STI kits with their corresponding use: A. Lower abdominal pain B. Urethral discharge C. Non herpetic genital ulcer D. Vaginal discharge 1. Grey, Kit 1 2. Green, Kit 2 3. White, Kit 3 4. Yellow, Kit 6

options.text: Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately

No fast breathing, no chest indrawing, no danger No pneumonia Home care, fluids, continued feeding, follow-up

Any general danger sign* or stridor in calm child Severe pneumonia Injectable antibiotics, urgent referral to hospital

questions.text: What is the duration after which the polymorphic rash of Varicella is no longer contagious?
questions.correct_answer: D. After crust formation over lesions
questions.explanation:
Agent

 
  • Varicella-zoster virus (HHV 3- Human Herpes Virus 3)
  • Double-stranded DNA virus.

Source of infection
 

 
  • Scabs are not infectious, but the vesicular fluid is infectious. (Option D)
  • Airborne- spreads via both droplet infection and droplet nuclei

Period of communicability

 
  • 1-2 days before and 4-5 days after the onset of the rash (crust formation)
  • Secondary attack rate- 85%

Host factors

 
  • Age: <10 years
  • Very common in school-going children
  • One attack gives lifelong immunity
  • Reactivation can occur as Varicella zoster infection in later age

Environmental factors
  • More common in winter and early spring
  • The virus can survive outside the body for 24-48 hours.
  • Disinfectants easily kill the virus.

Incubation period
  • More common in winter and early spring
  • The virus can survive outside the body for 24-48 hours.
  • Disinfectants easily kill the virus.

questions.text: Komal, a 2-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a high fever, cough, red eyes, and rash. Parents say that the rash started on the forehead and behind the ears, then subsequently spread to the neck and body. On examination, a confluent maculopapular rash is noted as shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this child's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The period of infectivity is 3 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash

options.label: B
options.text: The most common cause of death is subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

options.label: C
options.text: Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are associated with the disease

questions.correct_answer: B. The most common cause of death is subacute sclerosing panencephalitis
questions.explanation:
Measles

Causative agent
  • ssRNA paramyxovirus

Incubation period
  • 10 days from exposure to onset of fever and 14 days to the appearance of rash

Source of infection
  • Person with measles
  • Infective material

Period of communicability
  • Roughly 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash (Option A ruled out)

Clinical features

Prodromal stage:

  • Fever
  • Cough
  • Coryza with sneezing
  • Conjunctivitis with lacrimation
  • Koplik’s spots- grayish-white spots on the buccal mucosa (Pathognomonic feature) (Option D ruled out)

 

Eruptive stage:

  • Dusky red macular/maculopapular rash, which starts behind the ears and progresses to the face, neck and then to trunks and limbs.
  • In the absence of complications, the lesions and fever disappear after 3-4 days.

 

Post measles stage:

  • After the eruptive stage, it leads to weight loss, weakness, fatigue, diarrhea.

Isolation period
  • 7 days from the onset of rash

Difference between measles and rubella rash
  • Both rashes are maculopapular
  • The rash in measles is more confluent and botchy, whereas the rash in rubella is discrete or non-confluent.

Diagnosis
  • Clinically diagnosed based on rash and koplik’s spots
  • Gold standard: PCR

Treatment
  • No specific treatment
  • Symptomatic management only

Complications of Measles

Otitis Media

M/c complication in young children. Covered under IMNCI programme.

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE)

A rare, fatal brain disease that occurs years after measles infection, causing neurological damage and mortality. (Option B)

Pneumonia

Most common fatal complication & cause of death.

Persistent Diarrhea

Long-lasting diarrhea, potentially leading to protein-losing enteropathy.

Prevalent in developing countries, impacting infants significantly.

Keratomalacia

Measles causes acute vitamin A deficiency in children.

Giant Cell Pneumonia, Measles Inclusion-body Encephalitis

Primarily affects immunocompromised individuals.

Other complications: Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup), Encephalitis, Spontaneous abortion, Premature delivery

questions.text: Within what time frame should Cholera, a disease that requires notification, be reported to the World Health Organization?
Zika virus is transmitted by:
Which among the following regions is free from rabies?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C) Lakshadweep

Agent factor
  • Zoonotic disease with a 100% fatality rate
  • Lyssavirus type 1
    • Bullet-shaped RNA virus (Rhabdoviridae family).
  • Two Types of Viruses:
    • Street virus:
      • Cause natural infection (Rabies)
      • Variable incubation period (7 days-months)
    • Fixed virus:
      • Fixed incubation period (5-7 days)
      • For vaccine production.
      • It does not demonstrate Negri bodies.

Host factors
  • Occupation
    • Dog handlers
    • Forest workers
    • Veterinarians.

Transmission
  • Incubation period: 2-8 weeks
  • Animal bite: Dog, Cat, Monkey or Wild animal (all need vaccination)
  • Licks on abraded skin are considered as the route of transmission.
  • Rodent bites don't require vaccination.
  • Human bite is a very dangerous bite (no documented cases yet)
  • In India:
    • Urban Rabies is very common.
    • Rabies is not found around water-bounded areas (Lakshadweep and Andaman and Nicobar Islands) (Option C)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the hospital with fever, dry cough, sore throat, and muscle pain. RT-PCR confirmed the patient to be positive for COVID 19. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the epidemiology of Covid-19?

options.label: A
options.text: 1% Case Fatality rate in age ≥ 50 years

options.label: B
options.text: > 5% Case Fatality rate in age ≥ 80 years

options.label: C
options.text: Mode of transmission is droplets, contacts

options.label: D
options.text: Remdesivir is an emergency use authorization (EUA) from the FDA for COVID-19

questions.correct_answer: A. 1% Case Fatality rate in age ≥ 50 years
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - 1% Case Fatality rate in age ≥ 5

Aspect

COVID-19

Virus

  • SARS-CoV-2 (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2)

Disease

  • COVID-19 (Coronavirus Disease 2019)

Transmission

  • Respiratory droplets (coughing, sneezing, talking)

Incubation Period

  • 2-14 days (average: 5-6 days)

Symptoms

  • Fever

  • Cough

  • Shortness of breath

  • Fatigue

  • Body aches

  • Loss of taste or smell

Severity

  • Mild to severe (may result in hospitalization or death)

questions.text: African suburb, all population given chemoprophylaxis for Malaria. This is
questions.explanation:
Type of Prevention

Description

Focus

Example

Primordial Prevention

Targets social, economic, and environmental determinants of health to prevent the emergence of risk factors.

Addressing underlying causes of disease

Promoting healthy urban planning to reduce sedentary lifestyle and obesity.

Primary Prevention

Aims to prevent the occurrence of a disease or condition before it develops.

Reducing the risk of disease

Vaccination programs, health education on healthy lifestyle practices.

Secondary Prevention

Focuses on early detection and prompt treatment of a disease or condition to prevent its progression and minimize its impact.

Early detection and intervention

Regular screenings for breast cancer, HIV testing, and treatment.

Tertiary Prevention

Aims to manage and reduce the complications and disabilities associated with a disease to improve the quality of life of individuals already affected.

Managing complications and disabilities

Cardiac rehabilitation programs after a heart attack, physiotherapy for stroke patients.

questions.text: Which is the recommended chemoprophylaxis for an individual traveling to a region endemic for malaria?
questions.explanation:
Medication

Dosage

Indication

Common Side Effects

Chloroquine

300 mg once weekly

Areas with chloroquine-sensitive Plasmodium species

Nausea, headache, blurred vision

Atovaquone-Proguanil (Malarone)
  • Adult: 1 tablet daily
  • Pediatric: Weight-based dosage

Areas with chloroquine-resistant Plasmodium species

Abdominal pain, headache, nausea

Doxycycline
  • Adult: 100 mg daily
  • Pediatric: Weight-based dosage

Areas with chloroquine-resistant Plasmodium species

Nausea, sun sensitivity, gastrointestinal upset

Mefloquine
  • Adult: 250 mg once weekly
  • Pediatric: Weight-based dosage

Areas with chloroquine-resistant Plasmodium species

Nausea, dizziness, vivid dreams

questions.text: In the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme organization structure, which of the following centres is the furthest from the core?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Sub-Centre: The sub-centre is the first point of contact for healthcare services at the village level.
  • ↳ Sub-Centre:
  • ↳ Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC): The DMC is located at the primary healthcare level, such as a Primary Health Centre (PHC) or a sub-district level health facility.
  • ↳ Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC):
  • ↳ Primary Health Centre (PHC): The PHC is a higher-level primary healthcare facility that serves as a referral center for sub-centres.
  • ↳ Primary Health Centre (PHC):
  • ↳ Community Health Centre (CHC): The CHC is a secondary level healthcare facility that serves as a referral center for PHCs.
  • ↳ Community Health Centre (CHC):
  • ↳ District TB Centre (DTC): The DTC is responsible for overseeing and coordinating TB control activities at the district level. (Option A)
  • ↳ District TB Centre (DTC):
  • ↳ (Option A)
  • ↳ Intermediate Reference Laboratory (IRL): The IRL is typically located at the state or regional level. (Option B)
  • ↳ Intermediate Reference Laboratory (IRL):
  • ↳ (Option B)
  • ↳ Tuberculosis Unit (Option C): The Tuberculosis Unit refers to a health unit or department that is responsible for the diagnosis, treatment, and management of TB patients.
  • ↳ Tuberculosis Unit (Option C):

In ml 200-450 450-800 800-960 960-1600

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the likelihood of an infection occurring in a susceptible individual after coming into contact with an i nfectious person during the incubation period?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Secondary attack

questions.text: Which of the following options does not represent a method of direct transmission of communicable diseases ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Droplet nuclei (in bold letters)

Direct Transmission Indirect Transmission
  • Direct contact
    • E.g. Scabies, dermatitis
  • Vehicle borne
    • Blood borne - HIV, hepatitis
    • Food borne - GI infections, typhoid cholera.
    • Water borne - GI infections, typhoid, cholera
Droplet infection
  • Droplet nuclei
    • Air borne
    • Dust
    • Diseases: Measles, chickenpox, TB, influenza, covid 19.
  • Contact with soil
  • E.g. Tetanus
  • Vector borne
    • Mechanical vector
    • Biological vector - malaria
  • Inoculation into skin or mucosa
  • E.g. Dog bite, HIV by needle prick injury
  • Fomite borne: Non living thing or inanimate object.
    • Contaminated door handles, tables, chairs etc.
  • Vertical transmission
    • From mother to baby.
    • E.g.
      • 1st trimester - Rubella, chickenpox.
      • 2nd trimester - parvovirus
      • 3rd trimester - Toxoplasmosis, cytomegalovirus infection, hepatitis B, syphilis.
      • During delivery - HIV, Herpes.
  • Unclean hands and fingers
